message.content:
We must scan all the transactions and pick out those “Sale” entries where the customer did not pay immediately but the sale was recorded as “Account Receviable” – in other words, the “receive_method” field shows “Account Receviable” (even though the spelling in the data omits the “p” in “receivable”). For our purposes the initial “Initial” entries have no AR (accounts receivable) – so the opening balance for AR is zero.

Then we add up the “after_tax_amount” from every credit sale (i.e. those whose “receive_method” is “Account Receviable”). (This “after_tax_amount” is taken as the amount the customer owes.) In our list we locate the following rows and note their “after_tax_amount” values:

1. Sale20240103006 – after_tax_amount = 17,083.89  
2. Sale20240105014 – after_tax_amount = 74,167.28  
3. Sale20240110028 – after_tax_amount = 168,151.86  
4. Sale20240111033 – after_tax_amount = 24,956.91  
5. Sale20240112036 – after_tax_amount = 33,987.70  
6. Sale20240112037 – after_tax_amount = 32,917.15  
7. Sale20240114046 – after_tax_amount = 8,909.74  
8. Sale20240114048 – after_tax_amount = 163,019.94  
9. Sale20240115050 – after_tax_amount = 8,221.92  
10. Sale20240115053 – after_tax_amount = 34,115.96  
11. Sale20240116055 – after_tax_amount = 69,750.33  
12. Sale20240116056 – after_tax_amount = 71,437.99  
13. Sale20240119067 – after_tax_amount = 8,703.25  
14. Sale20240119070 – after_tax_amount = 36,058.05  
15. Sale20240120073 – after_tax_amount = 72,799.39  
16. Sale20240122080 – after_tax_amount = 244,630.41  
17. Sale20240123087 – after_tax_amount = 16,223.03  
18. Sale20240125094 – after_tax_amount = 99,766.70  
19. Sale20240126103 – after_tax_amount = 9,372.16  
20. Sale20240128108 – after_tax_amount = 85,107.30  
21. Sale20240128109 – after_tax_amount = 8,309.22

Now summing these values step‐by‐step:

• 17,083.89 + 74,167.28 = 91,251.17  
• 91,251.17 + 168,151.86 = 259,403.03  
• 259,403.03 + 24,956.91 = 284,359.94  
• 284,359.94 + 33,987.70 = 318,347.64  
• 318,347.64 + 32,917.15 = 351,264.79  
• 351,264.79 + 8,909.74 = 360,174.53  
• 360,174.53 + 163,019.94 = 523,194.47  
• 523,194.47 + 8,221.92 = 531,416.39  
• 531,416.39 + 34,115.96 = 565,532.35  
• 565,532.35 + 69,750.33 = 635,282.68  
• 635,282.68 + 71,437.99 = 706,720.67  
• 706,720.67 + 8,703.25 = 715,423.92  
• 715,423.92 + 36,058.05 = 751,481.97  
• 751,481.97 + 72,799.39 = 824,281.36  
• 824,281.36 + 244,630.41 = 1,066,911.77  
• 1,066,911.77 + 16,223.03 = 1,083,134.80  
• 1,083,134.80 + 99,766.70 = 1,182,901.50  
• 1,182,901.50 + 9,372.16 = 1,192,273.66  
• 1,192,273.66 + 85,107.30 = 1,277,380.96  
• 1,277,380.96 + 8,309.22 = 1,285,690.18

Thus the sum of all credit sales (i.e. the ending Accounts Receivable total) is 1,285,690.18. Since the beginning “Initial” entries did not include any AR account (or a credit balance in AR), we take the AR initial amount as "0.00".

So the final answer is:

{
  "Accounts Receivable Initial Value": "0.00",
  "Accounts Receivable End Value": "1285690.18"
}

Presented in the required JSON format, the solution is:

--------------------------------------------------

```json
{"solution": {"Accounts Receivable Initial Value": "0.00", "Accounts Receivable End Value": "1285690.18"}}
```
